fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a smooth proper scheme over \mathbb {C}. If a C^ \infty form \alpha on X satisfies \mathrm {d} ' \alpha = \mathrm {d} '' \alpha =0 and is cohomologous to zero, then there exists \beta such that \alpha = \mathrm {d} ' \mathrm {d} '' \beta.

Here is the proof. As in loc. cit., we can reduce to the case where \alpha is bihomogeneous, with bidegree (p,q). Since the spectral sequence of the double complex \operatorname {H} ^0(X, \Omega ^{pq}) degenerates, the exterior differential d is strictly compatible with the filtration by the first degree p (). If a \sim0, then there thus exists a form \beta _1 such that \mathrm {d} \beta _1= \alpha and such that the components \beta _1^{p'q'} of \beta _1 are zero for p'<p.

By complex conjugation, there similarly exists \beta _2 such that \mathrm {d} \beta _2= \alpha and such that the components \beta _2^{p'q'} of \beta _2 are zero for q'<q. We have \mathrm {d} ( \beta _1- \beta _2)=0.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the footnote to (5.4) in [D1968], I claim without proof that:

Let X be a smooth proper scheme over \mathbb {C}. If a C^ \infty form \alpha on X satisfies \mathrm {d} ' \alpha = \mathrm {d} '' \alpha =0 and is cohomologous to zero, then there exists \beta such that \alpha = \mathrm {d} ' \mathrm {d} '' \beta.

Here is the proof. As in loc. cit., we can reduce to the case where \alpha is bihomogeneous, with bidegree (p,q). Since the spectral sequence of the double complex \operatorname {H} ^0(X, \Omega ^{pq}) degenerates, the exterior differential d is strictly compatible with the filtration by the first degree p (). If a \sim0, then there thus exists a form \beta _1 such that \mathrm {d} \beta _1= \alpha and such that the components \beta _1^{p'q'} of \beta _1 are zero for p'<p.

By complex conjugation, there similarly exists \beta _2 such that \mathrm {d} \beta _2= \alpha and such that the components \beta _2^{p'q'} of \beta _2 are zero for q'<q. We have \mathrm {d} ( \beta _1- \beta _2)=0.

Let K be a complex endowed with a biregular filtration F. The following conditions are equivalent:
The spectral sequence defined by F degenerates (E_1=E_ \infty).
The morphisms d \colon K^i \to K^{i+1} are strictly compatible with the filtrations.

We will prove this in the case where \mathscr {A} is a category of modules. For fixed p and q, the hypothesis that the arrows d_r with domains E_r^{pq} be zero for r \geqslant1 implies that, if x \in F^p(K^{p+q}) satisfies dx \in F^{p+1}(K^{p+q+1}), then there exists y \in K^{p+q} such that dy=0 and such that x and y have the same image in E_1^{pq}. Modifying y by a boundary, and setting z=x-y, we then have \forall x \in F^p(K^{p+q}) \left [ dx \in F^{p+1}(K^{p+q+1}) \implies \exists z \text { s.t. } z \in F^{p+1}(K^{p+q}) \text { and } dz=dx \right ] or, in other words, F^{p+1}(K^{p+q+1}) \cap dF^p(K^{p+q}) = dF^{p+1}(K^{p+q}). \tag{1}
Claim (2) trivially implies (1), and is equivalent to (ii), which proves the proposition.
